2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: other_names        = Soap-Maker of Corregio (Italian: ''la Saponificatrice di Correggio'')
Italian]] [[serial killer]]. Better known as the '''\"Soap-Maker of Correggio\"''' (Italian: ''la Saponificatrice di Correggio''),<ref name=bbc>{{cite news
column4: title= Sodium: Getting rid of dirt - and murder victims
column6: publisher= [[BBC News]]}}</ref> she murdered three women in the town of [[Correggio, Italy
column8: Reggio Emilia]], between 1939 and 1940, and turned their bodies into soap and teacakes.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Leonarda Cianciulli was born in [[Montella]], [[Province of Avellino
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Avellino]]. While still a young girl, she attempted [[suicide]] twice. In 1917, Cianciulli married a [[Civil registry
column4: clerk]], Raffaele Pansardi. Her parents did not approve of the marriage, as they had planned to marry her to another man. Cianciulli claimed that on this occasion her mother cursed them. In 1921, the couple moved to Pansardi's native town of [[Lauria]], [[Province of Potenza
column5: Potenza]], where Cianciulli was sentenced and imprisoned for [[fraud]] in 1927. When released, the couple moved to [[Lacedonia
column6: Lacedonia, Avellino]]. After their home was destroyed in the [[1930 Irpinia earthquake]], they moved once more to [[Correggio, Italy
column8: Reggio Emilia]], where Cianciulli opened a small shop. She was very popular and well-respected within her neighborhood.<ref name=bbc/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Cianciulli had seventeen pregnancies during her marriage, but lost three of the children to [[miscarriage]]. Ten more died in their youth. Consequently, she was heavily protective of the four surviving children. Her fears were fueled by a warning she had received some time earlier from a [[fortune teller]], who said that she would marry and have children, but that all of the children would die young. Reportedly, Cianciulli also visited a [[Romani people
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Romani]] who practiced [[palm reading]], and who told her, \"In your right hand I see prison, in your left a criminal [[Psychiatric hospital
column8: archivedate=2006-09-12 }} Exhibit at Rome's Criminological Museum.</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: In 1939, Cianciulli learned that her eldest son and favourite child, Giuseppe, was going to join the [[Royal Italian Army
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Italian Army]] in preparation for [[World War II]]. She was determined to protect him at all costs, and came to the conclusion that his safety required [[human sacrifice]]s. Cianciulli found her victims in three middle-aged women, all neighbours.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: The first of Cianciulli's victims, Faustina Setti, was a lifelong [[spinster]] who had come to her for help in finding a husband. Cianciulli told her of a suitable partner in [[Pula
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Pola]], but asked her to tell no one of the news. She also persuaded Setti to write letters and postcards to relatives and friends. They were to be mailed when she reached Pola, to tell them that everything was fine. Preparing for her departure, Setti came to visit Cianciulli one last time. Cianciulli offered Setti a glass of drugged wine, then killed her with an axe and dragged the body into a closet. There she cut it into nine parts, gathering the blood into a basin. Cianciulli described what happened next in her official statement:

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: I threw the pieces into a pot, added seven kilos of caustic soda, which I had bought to make soap, and stirred the mixture until the pieces dissolved in a thick, dark mush that I poured into several buckets and emptied in a nearby septic tank. As for the blood in the basin, I waited until it had coagulated, dried it in the oven, ground it and mixed it with flour, sugar, chocolate, milk and eggs, as well as a bit of margarine, kneading all the ingredients together. I made lots of crunchy tea cakes and served them to the ladies who came to visit, though Giuseppe and I also ate them.
Some sources also record that Cianciulli apparently received Setti's life savings, 30,000 [[Italian lira
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: lire]], as payment for her services.<ref name=time>{{cite news
column4: title= Foreign News: A Copper Ladle

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Francesca Soavi was the second victim. Cianciulli claimed to have found her a job at a school for girls in [[Piacenza]]. Like Setti, Soavi was persuaded to write postcards to be sent to friends, this time from Correggio, detailing her plans. Also like Setti, Soavi came to visit with Cianciulli before her departure. She too was given drugged wine and then killed with an axe. The murder occurred on 5 September 1940. Soavi's body was given the same treatment as Setti's, and Cianciulli is said to have obtained 3,000 lire<ref name=time/> from her second victim.

Cianciulli's third and final victim was Virginia Cacioppo, a former [[soprano]] said to have sung at [[La Scala]]. For her, Cianciulli claimed to have found work as the secretary for a mysterious [[impresario]] in [[Florence]]. As with the other two women, she was instructed not to tell a single person where she was going. Cacioppo agreed, and on 30 September 1940, came for a last visit to Cianciulli. The pattern to the murder was the same as the first two. However, unlike the first two victims, Cacioppo's body was melted to make soap. According to Cianciulli's statement:

She ended up in the pot, like the other two...her flesh was fat and white, when it had melted I added a bottle of cologne, and after a long time on the boil I was able to make some most acceptable creamy soap. I gave bars to neighbours and acquaintances. The cakes, too, were better: that woman was really sweet.
From Cacioppo, Cianciulli reportedly received 50,000 lire, assorted jewels<ref name=time/> and public bonds. She even sold all the victims' clothing and shoes.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Leonarda Cianciulli: Creaba jabones con humanos

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Duarte was born in [[Massarelos]], [[Porto District]]. After playing youth football for local [[Boavista F.C.]] and starting out as a senior at [[C.F. União de Coimbra]], he signed for [[U.D. Leiria]] in 1988, also in the [[Segunda Liga

Duarte then played two seasons apiece for [[S.C. Salgueiros]] and [[C.S. Marítimo]], making his [[Primeira Liga]] debut with the former and appearing in a total of 84 league games the two clubs combined. Subsequently, he returned to Leiria who now competed in the [[Portuguese football league system
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Portuguese top flight]], retiring after almost one decade at the age of 34 and acting as first-choice in four of those campaigns (in [[2001–02 Primeira Liga
column3: 2001–02]], as the team [[2002 UEFA Intertoto Cup
column4: qualified]] for the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup]], he was managed by young [[José Mourinho]]).

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: After his retirement, Duarte immediately began his managerial career, staying with his last club Leiria as assistant. In the tenth round of [[2006–07 Primeira Liga

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: In late 2007, Duarte left Leiria<ref>[http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=613521.html Paulo Duarte leaves Leiria]; UEFA, 5 November 2007</ref> and, a couple of months later, was appointed manager of [[Burkina Faso national football team
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Burkina Faso]]. On 2 June 2009, however, he was signed by France's [[Le Mans FC
column3: Le Mans Union Club 72]] on a two-year contract while still working with the national side.<ref>[http://goal.com/en/news/11/transfer-zone/2009/06/02/1301254/le-mans-appoint-burkina-faso-coach-paulo-duarte-as-new Le Mans appoint Burkina Faso coach Paulo Duarte as new trainer]; [[Goal (website)

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Duarte was fired by Le Mans on 8 December 2009, becoming the first [[Ligue 1]] manager casualty in [[2009–10 Ligue 1
[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=710598&cc=5739 Le Mans sack coach Duarte]; [[ESPN FC
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: ESPN Soccernet]], 10 December 2009</ref> but still was on the bench for Burkina Faso's [[2010 Africa Cup of Nations]] campaign, exiting in the group stage after one draw and one loss (the team was in [[Togo national football team
column3: Togo]]'s group). On 17 February 2012, following three matches and as many losses at the [[2012 Africa Cup of Nations]], he was dismissed.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17075218 Burkina Faso coach gets the boot]; [[BBC Sport]], 17 February 2012</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: On 29 April 2012, Duarte was appointed interim coach of the [[Gabon national football team

column4: 2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>[https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=2179701.html Paulo Duarte fired by Gabon]; FIFA, 23 September 2013</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: In late December 2015, after a brief club spell with [[Tunisia]]'s [[CS Sfaxien]], Duarte was again named manager of Burkina Faso.<ref>[http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/made-in/africa/paulo-duarte-volta-a-ser-selecionador-do-burkina-faso Paulo Duarte volta a ser selecionador do Burkina Faso (Paulo Duarte is again head coach of Burkina Faso)]; Mais Futebol, 28 December 2015 (in Portuguese)</ref> He led the latter to the third place at the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]], after a 1–0 win against [[Ghana national football team

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: '''Mike and Ike''' is a brand of fruit-flavored [[Candy
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: candies]] that were first introduced in 1942 by the company [[Just Born]], Inc. The origin of the candy's name remains unknown, but there are many conjectures. Mike and Ikes were originally all fruit flavored but now come in several different varieties which have been introduced over the years.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: The Mike and Ike brand was first introduced in 1940 by Just Born, Inc., which is located in [[Bethlehem, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Encyclopedia of junk food and fast food
column7: accessdate=September 24, 2010}}</ref> Its origin uncertain, the name may have come from the comic strip [[Mike and Ike (They Look Alike)]], which, however, had ended by the 1940s. Or the name may have referred to the [[Matina Brothers]], two of whom, nicknamed \"Mike\" & \"Ike,\" were billed as circus midgets and had roles as [[Munchkin]]s in the 1939 film ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)
column8: The Wizard of Oz]]''; the author [[Dean Jensen]] wrote without cited evidence that the two became so popular in America that a boxed candy was named after them.<ref>{{cite book
column10: title=The Lives and Loves of Daisy and Violet Hilton: A True Story of Conjoined Twins
column16: accessdate=April 28, 2017}}</ref>  Other proposals include a company-wide contest, a [[vaudeville]] song titled “Mike and Ike”, and [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], whose nickname was \"Ike.\"<ref>{{cite web
column20: accessdate=November 22, 2017}}</ref> Just Born acquired the ''Rodda Candy Company'' in 1953 and produced new flavors of the candy, such as cotton candy. Additional flavors such as Root Beer came in the 1960s, and others have been introduced on and off since.<ref>{{cite web
column22: title=10 Sweet and Colorful Facts About Mike and Ike

The candy is [[kosher]] and [[gluten-free]].<ref>{{cite press release
column3: title=Fruity Facts about Mike and Ike

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: '''Mike and Ike''' is a brand of fruit-flavored [[Candy
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: candies]] that were first introduced in 1942 by the company [[Just Born]], Inc. The origin of the candy's name remains unknown, but there are many conjectures. Mike and Ikes were originally all fruit flavored but now come in several different varieties which have been introduced over the years.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: The Mike and Ike brand was first introduced in 1940 by Just Born, Inc., which is located in [[Bethlehem, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Encyclopedia of junk food and fast food
column7: accessdate=September 24, 2010}}</ref> Its origin uncertain, the name may have come from the comic strip [[Mike and Ike (They Look Alike)]], which, however, had ended by the 1940s. Or the name may have referred to the [[Matina Brothers]], two of whom, nicknamed \"Mike\" & \"Ike,\" were billed as circus midgets and had roles as [[Munchkin]]s in the 1939 film ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)
column8: The Wizard of Oz]]''; the author [[Dean Jensen]] wrote without cited evidence that the two became so popular in America that a boxed candy was named after them.<ref>{{cite book
column10: title=The Lives and Loves of Daisy and Violet Hilton: A True Story of Conjoined Twins
column16: accessdate=April 28, 2017}}</ref> . Other proposals include a company-wide contest, a [[vaudeville]] song titled “Mike and Ike”, and [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], whose nickname was \"Ike.\"<ref>{{cite web
column20: accessdate=November 22, 2017}}</ref> Just Born acquired the ''Rodda Candy Company'' in 1953 and produced new flavors of the candy, such as cotton candy. Additional flavors such as Root Beer came in the 1960s, and others have been introduced on and off since.<ref>{{cite web
column22: title=10 Sweet and Colorful Facts About Mike and Ike

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Mike and Ike are oblong fruit-flavored chewy candies that come in several colors and varieties, including cherry, orange, lime, lemon, and strawberry. Popular varieties are Tropical Typhoon, Berry Blast and Jolly Joes. Each candy has 7 calories, 0 grams of fat, and approximately 1 gram of sugar.  The candy is [[kosher]] and [[gluten-free]].<ref>{{cite press release
column3: title=Fruity Facts about Mike and Ike

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: The song \"Summer Moon\" started out as a different title, \"Surfer Moon\" which was previously recorded by [[Bob Norberg (musician)
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Bob Norberg]] & Sheri Pomeroy. In May 1963, Brian Wilson got together with some top [[Los Angeles]] session musicians who would later become [[The Wrecking Crew (music)
column3: The Wrecking Crew]]. This time Norberg recorded it with a local singer and future actress [[Victoria Hale (actress)
column4: Victoria Hale]], the song was recorded at [[United Western Recorders
column5: United Recorders]]. Jan Berry took care of the string arrangements.<ref>The Second Disc, December 17, 2013 - [https://theseconddisc.com/2013/12/17/the-beatles-and-the-beach-boys-beat-the-boots-on-the-big-beat-1963-and-bootleg-recordings/ NEWS, The Beatles and The Beach Boys Beat The Boots On “The Big Beat 1963” and “Bootleg Recordings” By Joe Marchese]</ref><ref>Casting Networks Inc. - [https://cni.castingnetworks.com/talent/profile/17240 VICTORIA HALE]</ref><ref>''The Words and Music of Brian Wilson'', By Christian Matijas-Mecca - {{ISBN
column6: 1440838984}} - [https://books.google.com/books?id=wmphDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA6&dq=%22Bob+%26+Sheri%22Surfer+Moon%22&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Bob%20&f=false Pages 6 - 7 '''Hits''']</ref> Victoria Hale was known as Vickie Kocher back then. Having already rehearsed their vocals at Norberg's Crenshaw Park apartment, they recorded the song at the Western Studio. Brian Wilson's vocals were also added to the recording.  A three track recording was done and Wilson had made a rough dub was made. Wilson also gave Kocher an acetate to have as a keepsake.<ref>''Becoming the Beach Boys, 1961-1963'', By James B. Murphy - [https://books.google.com/books?id=273eCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA289&dq=Becoming+the+Beach+Boys+Vickie+Kocher+Krenshaw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi6r9u65JbnAhVF8XMBHfqECLwQ6AEIKjAA#v=onepage&q=Becoming%20the%20Beach%20Boys%20Vickie%20Kocher%20Krenshaw&f=false Page 289 ''21. Making Waves in the Midwest (April - June 1963)'']</ref> According to the Friday Night Boys blog, Victoria Hale who possessed the only known acetate of \"The Summer Moon\" was contacted by David Beard of examiner.com. He put Alan Boyd and Mark Linett in touch with her. It was arranged for her to hand-carry her acetate to a professional mastering studio to make a digital transfer from it.<ref>Friday Night Boys, Saturday, 14 December 2013 - [https://fridaynightboys300.blogspot.com/2013/12/the-big-beat-1963.html Brian Wilson and The Big Beat 1963]</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: '''Vaginal steaming''', sometimes shortened to '''V-steaming''',<ref name=LiveScience>{{cite web
column4: title=No, Gwenyth Paltrow, Vaginas don't need to be steam cleaned
column10: ref=1}}</ref> and also known as '''yoni steaming''', is an [[Alternative medicine
column11: alternative health]] treatment whereby a woman squats or sits over steaming water containing herbs such as [[mugwort]], [[rosemary]], [[Artemisia (genus)
column12: wormwood]], and [[basil]]. It has been practiced in Africa ([[Mozambique]], [[South Africa]]<ref name=jwh/>), Asia ([[Indonesia]], [[Thailand]]<ref name=jwh>{{cite journal
column37: title=Prevalence, motivations, and adverse effects of vaginal practices in Africa and Asia: findings from a multicountry household survey.
column45: display-authors=1}}</ref>), and [[Central America]] (among the [[Q'eqchi' people]]<ref>{{cite book

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Vaginal steaming is described in spas as an [[Traditional Korean medicine
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: ancient Korean treatment]] for reproductive organ ailments and is claimed to have other benefits. No empirical evidence supports any of these claims.<ref name=\"Guardian-1\"/> It has become a fad for women in the Western world.<ref name=\"d\">{{cite web
column5: title=I Tried A Vaginal Steam Treatment, And Here's What Happened
column9: ref=5}}</ref> In a paper for ''[[Culture, Health & Sexuality]]'', Vandenburg and Braun argue that the rhetoric of vaginal steaming mirrors sexist Western discourse about the supposed inherent dirtiness of the female body, and that its claims of improved fertility and sexual pleasure continue the view that the female body exists for male sexual pleasure and childbearing.<ref name=VB/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: There is no [[evidence]] that Vaginal Steaming has any benefits,<ref name=HarvardHealth>https://www.health.harvard.edu/womens-health/what-is-vaginal-steaming</ref> and can be dangerous and can lead to [[Vaginal Yeast Infection]] by leading to an influx of [[bacteria]].<ref name=HarvardHealth />

According to a study on [[vagina]]l practices by the [[World Health Organization]] published in 2011, one of the ways in which women practice vaginal care is by \"Vaginal steaming or smoking: the 'steaming' or 'smoking' of the vagina, by sitting above a source of heat (fire, coals, hot rocks) on which water, herbs, or oils are placed to create steam or smoke\".<ref name=jwh/> For that study, over 4,000 women in  Tete (Mozambique), KwaZulu-Natal (South Africa), Yogyakarta (Indonesia), and Chonburi (Thailand) were asked about their vaginal care. When it came to vaginal steaming/smoking, very different results were obtained, and very different reasons were given: in Chonburi, 67% of women reported having performed vaginal steaming or smoking, \"which they associated with  maintaining  wellness  and  feminine  identity\", especially after [[Postpartum period
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: having given birth]] (85.5%). In Tete, only 10% of women practiced steaming or smoking, \"mostly intended to enhance male sexual pleasure by causing vaginal tightening (64.1% of users) and drying (22.9%)\". In the two African locations, 37–38% of women said they practiced it to enhance \"male sexual pleasure\"; in the two Asian ones, 0% gave that answer. Conversely, of the Asian women 26% reported their \"feminine identity\" was a reason, compared to 0% of the African women.<ref name=jwh/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: [[Side effect]]s and potential dangers include: [[allergic reactions]], [[second-degree burns]] if the steam is too close,<ref name=LiveScience/><ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=Second-Degree Burn Sustained After Vaginal Steaming
column5: journal=Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology Canada

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Vaginal steaming is marketed with pseudoscientific notions of \"balancing\" female hormones and \"revitalizing\" the [[uterus]] or vagina.<ref name=LiveScience/><ref name=\"Guardian-1\">{{cite news
column3: title=Sorry, Gwyneth Paltrow, but steaming your vagina is a bad idea
column11: title=Gwyneth Paltrow says steam your vagina, an OB/GYN says don’t
column13: work=Dr. Jen Gunter Wielding the Lasso of Truth
column14: date=27 January 2015}}</ref> It is also marketed as \"cleaning\" the vagina, which it does not do.<ref name=\"Guardian-1\"/><ref name=Gunter/>

2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: ''Goop'']], actress [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] in reviewing a Santa Monica, California spa, described several of their treatments and said of one, \"[y]ou sit on what is essentially a mini-throne, and a combination of infrared and mugwort steam cleanses your uterus, et al\".<ref name=\"Guardian-1\"/><ref name=\"LiveScience\"/> A report in ''[[The Guardian]]'' responded by debunking the claim of the heat, steam, and mugwort having any benefit, and noted it could be harmful.<ref name=\"Guardian-1\"/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: A 2017 survey by Vandenburg and Braun<ref name=VB>{{cite journal
column6: title=‘Basically, it’s sorcery for your vagina’: unpacking Western representations of vaginal steaming
column13: pmid=27719108}}</ref> (taking as its title one observer's characterization{{snd}}\"Basically, it's sorcery for your vagina\")<ref>{{cite article
column14: title=I Went To A Spa For My Uterus And This Is My Story

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: analyzed \"90 online items related to vaginal steaming\", including from newspapers and magazines, blogs, and providers of the practice. They identified a general theme, that of the \"self-improving woman\", which they argue fits in perfectly with modern constructions of what scholarship has called the \"neoliberal\" woman, a woman who, free of outside influences, seeks to optimize herself and her health (see [[Healthism]]). Within that theme, they found four attitudes that promote healthist practices such as vaginal steaming:

# The female body is inherently defective and dirty, and deteriorates with age: \"the female body [is] situated within this biologically-determinist narrative of inevitable decline\" which can be resisted.{{r

# Western medicine and bodily care (including tampon use, for instance) make the female genitalia unnaturally full of toxins, a process that can be reversed by the natural practice of vaginal steaming (the authors note that such accounts are themselves littered with language derived from Western medicine—\"symptoms\", \"decline\", \"ailments\").{{r

# Health enhancement, and the optimization of the body, specifically fertility and sexual pleasure, with much of the language used by advertisers of spas focusing on \"maintenance\" and \"restoration\", reinforcing both healthism and the fetishization of youth; vaginal steaming, it is claimed, improves marriages and the male libido. According to the authors, \"the sexual and reproductive enhancement focus mirrors the two modes through which Western societies have traditionally valued women: sexual availability for men (within marriage) and childbearing\".{{r

# The pampering of the self-assured woman, a luxury as well as a right that they have earned, with advertising playing on the \"reawakening\" of the \"inner goddess\": \"To awaken your inner goddess, please call us at...\" The idea is that the practice allows a woman to reach her true potential, her true self.{{r

The authors conclude that vaginal steaming is one of many practices that fit \"neoliberal, postfeminist and healthist ideologies, colliding with pervasive sociocultural understandings of the female reproductive body both as core of womanhood and as 'embodied pathology{{'\"}}.{{r

column9: ref=5}}</ref> In a paper for ''[[Culture, Health & Sexuality]]'', Vandenburg and Braun argue that the rhetoric of vaginal steaming mirrors sexist Western discourse about the supposed inherent dirtiness of the female body, and that its claims of improved fertility and sexual pleasure continue the view that the female body exists for male sexual pleasure and childbearing.<ref name=VB/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: There is no [[evidence]] that Vaginal Steaming has any benefits,<ref name=HarvardHealth>https://www.health.harvard.edu/womens-health/what-is-vaginal-steaming</ref> and can be dangerous and can lead to [[Vaginal Yeast Infection]] by leading to an influx of [[bacteria]].<ref name=HarvardHealth>

According to a study on [[vagina]]l practices by the [[World Health Organization]] published in 2011, one of the ways in which women practice vaginal care is by \"Vaginal steaming or smoking: the 'steaming' or 'smoking' of the vagina, by sitting above a source of heat (fire, coals, hot rocks) on which water, herbs, or oils are placed to create steam or smoke\".<ref name=jwh/> For that study, over 4,000 women in  Tete (Mozambique), KwaZulu-Natal (South Africa), Yogyakarta (Indonesia), and Chonburi (Thailand) were asked about their vaginal care. When it came to vaginal steaming/smoking, very different results were obtained, and very different reasons were given: in Chonburi, 67% of women reported having performed vaginal steaming or smoking, \"which they associated with  maintaining  wellness  and  feminine  identity\", especially after [[Postpartum period
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: having given birth]] (85.5%). In Tete, only 10% of women practiced steaming or smoking, \"mostly intended to enhance male sexual pleasure by causing vaginal tightening (64.1% of users) and drying (22.9%)\". In the two African locations, 37–38% of women said they practiced it to enhance \"male sexual pleasure\"; in the two Asian ones, 0% gave that answer. Conversely, of the Asian women 26% reported their \"feminine identity\" was a reason, compared to 0% of the African women.<ref name=jwh/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: [[Side effect]]s and potential dangers include: [[allergic reactions]], [[second-degree burns]] if the steam is too close,<ref name=LiveScience/><ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=Second-Degree Burn Sustained After Vaginal Steaming
column5: journal=Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology Canada

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Vaginal steaming is marketed with pseudoscientific notions of \"balancing\" female hormones and \"revitalizing\" the [[uterus]] or vagina.<ref name=LiveScience/><ref name=\"Guardian-1\">{{cite news
column3: title=Sorry, Gwyneth Paltrow, but steaming your vagina is a bad idea
column11: title=Gwyneth Paltrow says steam your vagina, an OB/GYN says don’t
column13: work=Dr. Jen Gunter Wielding the Lasso of Truth
column14: date=27 January 2015}}</ref> It is also marketed as \"cleaning\" the vagina, which it does not do.<ref name=\"Guardian-1\"/><ref name=Gunter/>

2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: ''Goop'']], actress [[Gwyneth Paltrow]] in reviewing a Santa Monica, California spa, described several of their treatments and said of one, \"[y]ou sit on what is essentially a mini-throne, and a combination of infrared and mugwort steam cleanses your uterus, et al\".<ref name=\"Guardian-1\"/><ref name=\"LiveScience\"/> A report in ''[[The Guardian]]'' responded by debunking the claim of the heat, steam, and mugwort having any benefit, and noted it could be harmful.<ref name=\"Guardian-1\"/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: A 2017 survey by Vandenburg and Braun<ref name=VB>{{cite journal
column6: title=‘Basically, it’s sorcery for your vagina’: unpacking Western representations of vaginal steaming
column13: pmid=27719108}}</ref> (taking as its title one observer's characterization{{snd}}\"Basically, it's sorcery for your vagina\")<ref>{{cite article
column14: title=I Went To A Spa For My Uterus And This Is My Story

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: analyzed \"90 online items related to vaginal steaming\", including from newspapers and magazines, blogs, and providers of the practice. They identified a general theme, that of the \"self-improving woman\", which they argue fits in perfectly with modern constructions of what scholarship has called the \"neoliberal\" woman, a woman who, free of outside influences, seeks to optimize herself and her health (see [[Healthism]]). Within that theme, they found four attitudes that promote healthist practices such as vaginal steaming:

# The female body is inherently defective and dirty, and deteriorates with age: \"the female body [is] situated within this biologically-determinist narrative of inevitable decline\" which can be resisted.{{r

# Western medicine and bodily care (including tampon use, for instance) make the female genitalia unnaturally full of toxins, a process that can be reversed by the natural practice of vaginal steaming (the authors note that such accounts are themselves littered with language derived from Western medicine—\"symptoms\", \"decline\", \"ailments\").{{r

# Health enhancement, and the optimization of the body, specifically fertility and sexual pleasure, with much of the language used by advertisers of spas focusing on \"maintenance\" and \"restoration\", reinforcing both healthism and the fetishization of youth; vaginal steaming, it is claimed, improves marriages and the male libido. According to the authors, \"the sexual and reproductive enhancement focus mirrors the two modes through which Western societies have traditionally valued women: sexual availability for men (within marriage) and childbearing\".{{r

# The pampering of the self-assured woman, a luxury as well as a right that they have earned, with advertising playing on the \"reawakening\" of the \"inner goddess\": \"To awaken your inner goddess, please call us at...\" The idea is that the practice allows a woman to reach her true potential, her true self.{{r

The authors conclude that vaginal steaming is one of many practices that fit \"neoliberal, postfeminist and healthist ideologies, colliding with pervasive sociocultural understandings of the female reproductive body both as core of womanhood and as 'embodied pathology{{'\"}}.{{r

2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: gross          = $1.4 million (US rentals)<ref>\"Top Grosses of 1957\", ''Variety'', 8 January 1958: 30</ref>

2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Terence Young]] with assistance from [[John Gilling]] and [[Yakima Canutt]]. Set in the [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa
column3: Northwest Frontier]] and [[Afghanistan]] (though filmed in [[Morocco]]), the film stars [[Victor Mature]], [[Michael Wilding (actor)
column4: Michael Wilding]], [[Anita Ekberg]], and features [[Patrick McGoohan]] in a supporting role.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Zarak Khan ([[Victor Mature]]) is the son of a chief, who is caught embracing one of his father's wives Salma ([[Anita Ekberg]]). Zarak's father sentenced both to torture and death but they are saved by an [[Imam]] ([[Finlay Currie]]). The exiled Zarak becomes a bandit chief and an enemy of the British Empire.

2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Michael Wilding]] as Maj. Michael Ingram

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: The film is based on a 1950 book, written by A.J. Bevan, which contained a foreword by Field Marshal [[William Slim]].<ref>War-Time Enterprises and Escapes: AN OCEAN WITHOUT SHORES

Jennings, C O; Bentwich, Norman; Bevan, A J. The Scotsman (1921-1950) [Edinburgh, Scotland] 20 July 1950: 9</ref> According to Bevan, the real Zarak Khan was an Afghan who spent most of his life fighting the British in the northwest frontier in the 1920s and 1930s. Among his crimes was the murder of a holy man. He eventually gave himself up and was sentenced to life imprisonment in the [[Andaman Islands]]. However, when the Japanese occupied the islands he stayed in his cell.

Khan was eventually given a suspended sentence and decided to work for the British in Burma. In 1943 he was leading a patrol when its British officer was killed in an ambush. He watched another British patrol be attacked by the Japanese and sent messengers to summon a [[Gurkha]] force. To stop the Japanese from escaping with their prisoners before the Gurkhas arrived, he attacked them single-handed, and killed or wounded six soldiers before being overpowered. He refused to be beheaded and insisted on being [[flayed alive]] to buy time to enable the Gurkhas to arrive.<ref>{{cite news
column11: page=1, Magazine section}} At [[Trove]], [[National Library of Australia]]</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: [[Warwick Films]] bought the film rights in 1953. Producer [[Irving Allen]] said he was more interested in the character of Zarak Khan than the events described in the book. He was contemplating changing Khan's nationality in order to offer the role to [[Errol Flynn]].<ref>Pryor, Thomas. \"Warwick acquires Bevan spy novel: Irving Allen Plans Production of 'Zarak Khan' —-Seeking Errol Flynn for Title Role\". ''[[The New York Times]]'', 14 May 1953: p. 33. Retrieved 10 June 2016</ref> Eventually Allen decided to make a fictional account set in the 19th century.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref> Regular Warwick writer [[Richard Maibaum]] was assigned the job of writing the script.<ref>HOPEFUL HOLLYWOOD: Production Step-Up Augurs Industry's Return to Former Activity -- Addenda

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: By THOMAS M. PRYOR HOLLYWOOD,. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 23 May 1954: X5.</ref>
The movie starred [[Victor Mature]], who had signed a two-picture deal with Warwick.<ref>TV PACT IS SIGNED BY SCREEN GUILD: Agreement by Du Mont and Union Includes Use of New Video Filming Method
By THOMAS M. PRYOR Special to The New York Times.. New York Times (1923-Current file) [New York, N.Y] 09 May 1955: 28</ref> He made the film after making ''Safari'' for the company.

Filming started in Morocco on 1 November 1955 with [[Yakima Canutt]] in charge of the second unit. Victor Mature joined the production on 19 November.<ref>Drama: 'Time for Love' Bought; Gregory Sets Play, Film; 'Powder Keg' Purchased
SHCALLERT, EDWIN. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 01 Nov 1955: B9.</ref>

[[Ted Moore]], who handled some of the Technicolor/CinemaScope photography, later performed similar work on the early [[James Bond]] films, and art director John Box and costume designer Phyllis Dalton later won Oscars for their work on ''[[Doctor Zhivago (1965 film)
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Doctor Zhivago]]''. [[Richard Maibaum]], who adapted [[A. J. Bevan]]'s novel, went on to adapt such [[Ian Fleming]] novels as ''[[Dr. No (novel)
column5: Goldfinger]]''. Similarly, the director, Terence Young and co-producer, Albert R. Broccoli went on to create the Bond movies.

2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Bob Simmons]], who performed and doubled several stars in the film, noted that Victor Mature refused to ride a horse. When his stunt double Jack Keely was killed in a horse accident on the set, Mature insisted on personally paying for his funeral.<ref>Simmons, Bob & Passingham, Kenneth ''Nobody Does It Better: My 25 Years of Stunts With James Bond and Other Stories'' Sterling Pub Co Inc (October 1987)</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: [[Patrick McGoohan]] portrays Moor Larkin, an [[adjutant]] to Michael Wilding's character who has a penchant for billiards, as well as offering sensible, albeit ignored, advice. This role was commented on in the British cinema magazine, Picturegoer.{{citation needed
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: date=June 2016}} The critic Margaret Hinxman made Patrick McGoohan her \"Talent Spot\". She assured readers that this new face would be \"really something\", given a \"half-decent\" part.  She completely slated the film, however, describing it as \"absurd\".{{citation needed

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: The popular chanteuse Yana sang her hit song ''Climb Up the Wall'' in the film.<ref>{{cite web

Allen says the film was profitable.<ref>{{cite magazine

'''Stanley I. Chera''' (October 22, 1942 – April 11, 2020) was an American [[real estate developer]] and founder of Crown Acquisitions.<ref name=NYT30Minute>{{cite news
Chera was born in 1942 in [[Brooklyn]] to a [[History of the Jews in Syria
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Syrian Jewish]] family.<ref name=NYT30Minute /><ref name=RealDealSyrianRetail>[http://therealdeal.com/issues_articles/the-syrian-retail-touch/ The Real Deal: \"The Syrian retail touch - An inside look at the Syrian Jewish investors dominating NYC retail — from Sutton to Sitt, including how much revenue they’re pulling in\" By Adam Pincus ] January 1, 2014</ref><ref>[http://therealdeal.com/issues_articles/clans-with-plans/ The Real Deal: \"Clans with Plans\" by Adam Pincus] February 1, 2011</ref><ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Crown Acquisitions Founder Stanley Chera Dies of Coronavirus
column8: access-date=April 12, 2020}}</ref> In 1947,<ref name=NYT30Minute /> his father Isaac Chera opened a retail store called ''Young World'' in [[Brooklyn, New York]].<ref name=RealDealSyrianRetail /> The family later purchased the building and grew ''Young World'' into a chain purchasing the buildings as they expanded.<ref name=RealDealSyrianRetail />

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: In the 1980s, Chera (then in charge of the family company) started purchasing real estate in New York City<ref name=\"NYT30Minute\" /> at first as a minority partner and later in 2000s as the lead developer.<ref name=\"RealDealSyrianRetail\" /> Chera was known for developing or \"repositioning\" the retail portion of his buildings and then selling the property.<ref name=\"RealDealSyrianRetail\" />

In a joint venture with [[The Carlyle Group]] and [[Charles Kushner]], Chera sold the retail portion of [[666 Fifth Avenue]] in two transactions for more than $1 billion;<ref name=RealDeal650Madison>[http://therealdeal.com/blog/2013/06/03/crown-highgate-to-pay-1-3b-for-650-madison/ The Real Deal: \"$1.3B sale of 650 Madison hinges on dramatic increase in retail value, sources say\" by Adam Pincus] June 3, 2013</ref> and also the retail portion of the [[The St. Regis Hotel
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: St. Regis Hotel]] in a joint venture with [[Lloyd Goldman]] and [[Jeffrey Feil]] for $380 million.<ref name=JewishVoice650>[http://jewishvoiceny.com/index.php?option=com_content&id=4317:chera-familys-crown-acquisitions-buys-650-madison-for-13-billion&Itemid=299 Jewish Voice New York: \"Chera Family’s Crown Acquisitions Buys 650 Madison for $1.3 Billion\"  By Boruch Shubert] June 5, 2013</ref> In 2010, he began the restoration of [[The Knickerbocker Hotel (Manhattan)
column3: The Knickerbocker Hotel]] in Manhattan.<ref name=NYT30Minute /><ref>[http://therealdeal.com/blog/2010/06/28/stanley-chera-dishes-on-the-knickerbocker-1/ The Real Deal: \"Stanley Chera dishes on the Knickerbocker\"] June 28, 2010</ref> In 2012, Chera purchased 49.9% interest in a four-building Fifth Avenue portfolio that included the [[Olympic Tower]] for $1 billion from the Alexander S. Onassis Public Benefit Foundation.<ref>[http://therealdeal.com/blog/2012/05/14/crown-acquisitions-takes-stake-in-1b-fifth-ave-portfolio/ The Real Deal: \"Crown takes stake in $1B Fifth Avenue portfolio\"] May 14, 2012</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: In June 2013, Chera purchased 650 Madison Avenue for $1.3 billion in partnership with Highgate Holdings from the Carlyle Group.<ref name=RealDeal650Madison /><ref name=JewishVoice650 /> He was an investor in the [[One World Trade Center]]<ref name=NYT30Minute /> and accumulated a lot of property in [[Red Hook, Brooklyn]].<ref name=NYT30Minute /> Crown is also a prominent investor (along with [[Albert Laboz]], Joseph Jemal, and [[Gindi family
column3: Fulton Mall]] in Brooklyn.<ref>[http://therealdeal.com/issues_articles/families-plot-fulton-mall-face-lift/ The Real Deal: \"Families plot Fulton Mall face-lift - A parcel-by-parcel look at what the corridor's tight-knit group of owners has in store\" By Patrick Egan] January 31, 2011</ref> Chera had a conservative investment strategy borrowing no more than 25 to 35% of the purchase price<ref name=NYT30Minute /> given that they are long term holders in assets.<ref name=RealDealSyrianRetail /> In 2009, Crown held 15 million square feet of real estate in New York City.<ref>[http://observer.com/2009/11/bigtime-fight-over-st-regis-retail-chera-cries-conspiracy-in-lawsuit/?show=all New York Observer: \"Big-Time Fight Over St. Regis Retail; Chera Cries ‘Conspiracy’ in Lawsuit\" By Dana Rubinstein] November 10, 2009</ref>

Chera was born in 1942 in [[Brooklyn]] to a [[History of the Jews in Syria
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Syrian Jewish]] family.<ref name=NYT30Minute /><ref name=RealDealSyrianRetail>[http://therealdeal.com/issues_articles/the-syrian-retail-touch/ The Real Deal: \"The Syrian retail touch - An inside look at the Syrian Jewish investors dominating NYC retail — from Sutton to Sitt, including how much revenue they’re pulling in\" By Adam Pincus ] January 1, 2014</ref><ref>[http://therealdeal.com/issues_articles/clans-with-plans/ The Real Deal: \"Clans with Plans\" by Adam Pincus] February 1, 2011</ref><ref>{{Cite web

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: '''Warren Brown''' (August 11, 1836 – September 19, 1919) was an American politician, historian, gentleman farmer, businessman, and author from [[Hampton Falls, New Hampshire]].

Warren Brown was born in [[Hampton Falls, New Hampshire]], the only child of John Berry and Sarah March Leavitt Brown.  He was educated in the North School in Hampton Falls, the old Rockingham Academy in [[Hampton, New Hampshire
column3: Phillips-Andover Academy]] in [[Andover, Massachusetts]].<ref>Brown, Warren. ''History of Hampton Falls N.H. Vol. II''. 1918. Rumford Press. [[Concord, New Hampshire]]</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Brown married [[Sarah Gertrude Norris]] on January 1, 1867.<ref name=WB75>{{cite news
column8: via=newspapers.com}}</ref> Sarah was a native of [[Raymond, New Hampshire
column9: Raymond]] and [[Dover, New Hampshire]], and a daughter of Daniel L. Norris and Sophia (Osgood) Norris, born November 17, 1841.  She was raised by her aunt Lavinia Osgood Meserve (Mrs. Samuel) in [[Lowell, Massachusetts]], where she received her education.  She subsequently moved to Hampton, where she taught in the public schools until her marriage. Warren and Sarah had five children:

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: *Arthur Warren (July 20, 1873 – 1960) married Frances Wadleigh (1881–1966) on October 11, 1906
* Mildred Leavitt (April 3, 1880 – December 5, 1965) married Roscoe Franklin Swain (1881–1946) on June 11, 1908

Sarah Brown died on January 24, 1917, after celebrating the couple's Golden Wedding anniversary on January 1 of that year. She was eulogized by her husband as being a \"person of great executive ability and force of character.\"
Brown had a lifelong interest in agricultural matters. He managed and worked one of the largest and most productive farms in [[Rockingham County, New Hampshire
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Rockingham County]]. His farm included orchards, salt marsh, dairy cattle, sheep and gardens sufficient to maintain his family and the employees for whom he provided room and board.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Brown was president of the [[New Hampshire State Agricultural Society]] for eleven years, treasurer of the [[New England Agricultural Society]] for twenty-five years, trustee of the [[New Hampshire College of Agriculture and the Mechanic Arts]] for 24 years, including four years served as Chairman of the Board.
In addition to agricultural interests, Brown was active in state politics. He was a state senator in 1872–73, a member of the state's [[Executive Council of New Hampshire
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Executive Council]] from 1879 to 1881 during the term of [[Nathaniel Head
column3: Natt Head]] as Governor, and a delegate to [[1884 Republican National Convention]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].<ref name=WB75/> He was a state representative in 1887, and a presidential elector in [[1908 United States presidential election
column5: Freemason]].<ref name=WB75/> Brown was a stockholder and active promoter of the electric railways in southern New Hampshire,<ref>{{cite news
column12: via=newspapers.com}}</ref> and owned and operated a sawmill on his estate.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Brown was a true native son, descended from many of the original settlers of the [[Seacoast Region (New Hampshire)
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: New Hampshire Seacoast Region]], and very interested in his town's history. He wrote a two-volume history of Hampton Falls: ''History of Hampton Falls, N.H. Volume I'' and ''History of Hampton Falls, N.H. Volume II''. Volume I spans from 1640 to 1900, while Volume II spans from 1900 to 1917.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Brown died September 19, 1919.  He was buried in the family lot in the Westview Cemetery of Hampton Falls. He was predeceased by his wife Sarah, his daughter Gertrude and his son Harry.

column4: Brown's residence, Sunnyside, as published in his ''History of Hampton Falls, N.H.'']]

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Brown owned and operated a highly successful farm on family land purchased by his father in 1812. On this property, in 1880, he built a [[Victorian house
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Victorian style home]] which replaced his parents' center-chimney [[American colonial architecture
column3: colonial]] house. This new home, called Sunnyside, was designed by his beloved wife Sarah Gertrude; architectural plans were drawn for her by a Mr. Bruce of [[Newburyport, Massachusetts]].  The house remained in the family until the 1960s.  Its unique presence in a town of mainly colonial styled architecture, its resemblance to [[The Addams Family (1964 TV series)
column4: ''The Addams Family'']] house and the years between owners when it was vacant, have perhaps helped to make it the source of speculation by locals and newcomers alike.

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: For many years, a rumor circulated stating that Brown made an unsuccessful run for [[Governor of New Hampshire]] and that his Victorian style house was built in anticipation of its being \"the Governor's mansion\", a name it became known by. In truth, his wife Sarah, a woman of innovation and industry, designed Sunnyside to be a practical and beautiful home where the couple could entertain in style and operate their large estate with efficiently. After numerous experiences, the current owners have brought in many paranormal teams to prove spectral activity on this property and had it investigated in 2012 by [[The Atlantic Paranormal Society]] ( T.A.P.S.) for the [[Syfy]] television series [[Ghost Hunters (TV series)
column4: title=‘Haunted in New England’ to film at Hampton Falls mansion
column10: quote=The home was built around 1880 by Warren Brown, a prominent New Hampshire politician.}}</ref>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Brown Road, abutting his former property in Hampton Falls, is named for Warren Brown.

On April 17, 2006, a group of Hampton Falls people formed the Warren Brown Foundation and created a website. The Foundation was dedicated to \"discovering the Brown family's past and improving what is left.\" The group has since been discontinued as it was the act of uninformed newcomers who discovered the family had not disappeared into obscurity.  Many of Warren and Sarah Brown's descendants still live in the greater Hampton Falls area and take umbrage at the rewriting of their family's history.

2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: Crowell, Suzanne Perfect]]. ''Sunnyside Files''. 1976. Offset House, [[South Burlington, Vermont]].

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: * Diaries of Warren and Sarah Brown
* Newspaper clipping from \"The Union,\" dated August 11. 1919
* Brown, Marguerite Willette ''Genealogy of John Brown of Hampton, New Hampshire, ''1977, '' ''Hillside Publishing Co., Amesbury MA 01913
* Interviews with descendants of Warren and Sarah Brown

column3: title=A Good Farm and a Good Farmer

[[Category:Members of the New Hampshire Executive Council]]
'''Edward Douglas Fawcett''' (11 April 1866 – 14 April 1960) was an English mountaineer, philosopher and novelist.
Edward Douglas Fawcett was born in [[Hove]], Sussex on 11 April 1866.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite book
column7: page=84}}</ref> He was the elder son of [[Edward Fawcett]], an [[equerry]] to the [[Prince of Wales]], (King Edward VII)<ref name=\"Times\">\"Mr. Douglas Fawcett.\" Times, 18 April 1960, p. 10</ref> and the older brother of explorer [[Percy Fawcett]]. He was educated at [[Newton Abbot College]] in Devon and was a Queen's Scholar at [[Westminster School]] from 1880.<ref name=\"Times\"/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Fawcett converted to [[Buddhism]], having taken the pansil (the [[Laity
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: lay]] follower vow to the [[Five Precepts]]) while with [[Henry Steel Olcott]] in [[Ceylon]] (modern Sri Lanka) in January 1890.<ref>{{cite book
column12: title=The Buddhist Propaganda in Christian Countries
column22: location=London}}</ref> He was an associate of Russian occultist [[Helena Blavatsky]], leading theoretician of the esoteric religious movement [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)
column23: Theosophy]].  He assisted her in her writing and in compiling quotations from scientific works for ''[[The Secret Doctrine]]''<ref>{{cite book
column26: title=Reminiscences of H. P. Blavatsky and 'The Secret Doctrine'
column32: accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref> and particularly the parts of second volume on the topic of evolutionary hypotheses.<ref>{{cite book
column35: title=Reminiscences of H. P. Blavatsky and 'The Secret Doctrine'
column41: accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref> Fawcett joined the editorial staff of [[The Theosophist]], the monthly journal of the [[Theosophical Society]]<ref name=\"Lucifer161\">{{cite journal
column49: accessdate=6 July 2018}}</ref> and wrote correspondence for the magazine ''[[Lucifer (magazine)
column54: title=Theosophical Activities – From Our Far East Station

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: As a science fiction author, Fawcett published his first fantasy novel ''[[Hartmann the Anarchist]]'' in 1893.<ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=Classics of Science Fiction and Fantasy
column10: accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref> He published two adventure novels in the 1890s.  His 1894 novel ''Swallowed by an Earthquake'' drew favourable comparisons in London to the works of Jules Verne.<ref>{{cite journal
column11: title=A Weekly Review of Literature, Science, and Art

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: He also authored multiple books on philosophy, including ''The Riddle of the Universe'' in 1893 on the [[metaphysical]] concept of [[Monadology]].<ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=The Key to the Riddle of the Universe. A Disquisition on Mr. Edward Douglas Fawcett's Philosophy

Fawcett returned to England and in 1947, he married his second wife, Vera Dick-Cunyngham, widow of George Dick-Cunyngham.  Fawcett died in London on 14 April 1960.<ref name=\"auto1\"/>

'''Edward Douglas Fawcett''' (11 April 1866 – 14 April 1960) was an English mountaineer, philosopher and novelist.
Edward Douglas Fawcett was born in [[Hove]], Sussex on 11 April 1866.<ref name=\"auto\">{{cite book
column7: page=84}}</ref> He was the elder son of [[Edward Fawcett]], an [[equerry]] to the [[Prince of Wales]], (King Edward VII)<ref name=\"Times\">\"Mr. Douglas Fawcett.\" Times, 18 April 1960, p. 10</ref> and the older brother of explorer [[Percy Fawcett]]. He was educated at [[Newton Abbot College]] in Devon and was a Queen's Scholar at [[Westminster School]] from 1880.<ref name=\"Times\"/>

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: Fawcett converted to [[Buddhism]], having taken the pansil (the [[Laity
2018 film directed by Andrew Slater}}: lay]] follower vow to the [[Five Precepts]]) while with [[Henry Steel Olcott]] in [[Ceylon]] (modern Sri Lanka) in January 1890.<ref>{{cite book
column12: title=The Buddhist Propaganda in Christian Countries
column22: location=London}}</ref> He was an associate of Russian occultist [[Helena Blavatsky]], leading theoretician of the esoteric religious movement [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)
column23: Theosophy]].  He assisted her in her writing and in compiling quotations from scientific works for the''[[The Secret Doctrine]]''<ref>{{cite book
column26: title=Reminiscences of H. P. Blavatsky and 'The Secret Doctrine'
column32: accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref> and particularly the parts of second volume on the topic of evolutionary hypotheses.<ref>{{cite book
column35: title=Reminiscences of H. P. Blavatsky and 'The Secret Doctrine'
column41: accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref> Fawcett joined the editorial staff of [[The Theosophist]], the monthly journal of the [[Theosophical Society]]<ref name=\"Lucifer161\">{{cite journal
column49: accessdate=6 July 2018}}</ref> and wrote correspondence for the magazine ''[[Lucifer (magazine)
column54: title=Theosophical Activities – From Our Far East Station

clean up,MOS:HEADCAPS,safe,Titodutta,"{{: As a science fiction author, Fawcett published his first fantasy novel ''[[Hartmann the Anarchist]]'' in 1893.<ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=Classics of Science Fiction and Fantasy
column10: accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref> He published two adventure novels in the 1890s.  His 1894 novel ''Swallowed by an Earthquake'' drew favourable comparisons in London to the works of Jules Verne.<ref>{{cite journal
column11: title=A Weekly Review of Literature, Science, and Art
